title: Fatehpur Sikri
summary: Fatehpur Sikri, located in Agra District, Uttar Pradesh, India, was founded as the capital of the Mughal Empire by Emperor Akbar in 1571. It served as the capital from 1571 to 1585, eventually being completely abandoned in 1610. The city's construction was partly motivated by the birth of Akbar's son, Jahangir, which was predicted by Sheikh Salim Chishti. Named the "City of Victory" after Akbar's successful Gujarat campaign in 1573, archaeological evidence indicates prior settlements existed here. After Mughal abandonment, the East India Company used it as an administrative center from 1803 to 1850. Recognizing its profound historical and architectural significance, Fatehpur Sikri was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986, preserving its legacy as a pivotal Mughal imperial city.
key_points: Founded by Emperor Akbar in 1571, serving as the Mughal Empire's capital from 1571 to 1585.
Abandoned in 1610, partly due to Akbar's campaign in Punjab and later complete abandonment.
Named 'Fatehpur Sikri' or 'City of Victory' after Akbar's successful Gujarat campaign in 1573.
Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986 due to its historical importance and outstanding architecture.
Pre-Mughal settlements, including housing, temples, and commercial centers, were identified by Archaeological Survey of India excavations.
The construction was linked to the birth of Jahangir, Akbar's son, predicted by Sheikh Salim Chishti.
categories: UNESCO World Heritage Sites in India
timeline: 7th to 16th century CE: Region controlled by Kanyakubja Brahmins or Bhumihar Brahmins.
1527: Battle of Khanwa, preceding Mughal control of the area.
1569: Jahangir, Akbar's son, is born in Sikri; Akbar begins construction of a religious compound.
1571: Emperor Akbar founds Fatehpur Sikri as the new capital of the Mughal Empire.
1573: City is named Fatehpur Sikri (City of Victory) after Akbar's Gujarat campaign.
1585: Akbar abandons Fatehpur Sikri as the capital due to a campaign in Punjab.
1803: East India Company establishes an administrative center in Fatehpur Sikri.
1815: Marquess of Hastings orders the repair of monuments at Sikri.
1850: East India Company administrative center ceases operation.
1986: Fatehpur Sikri is awarded UNESCO World Heritage Site status.
1999-2000: Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) excavation indicates prior settlements.
important_figures: Sheikh Salim Chishti (Sufi saint whose prophecy influenced Akbar's construction)
Marquess of Hastings (ordered monument repairs in 1815)
East India Company (established an administrative center)
applications: Served as the imperial capital of the Mughal Empire.
Functioned as an administrative center under the East India Company.
Site of religious significance due to Sheikh Salim Chishti's khanqah.
Currently serves as a major tourist attraction and historical site.
Provides an important site for archaeological research into pre-Mughal and Mughal periods.
current_status: Fatehpur Sikri is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the Agra District of Uttar Pradesh, India. It stands as a well-preserved example of Mughal architecture and history, attracting tourists and researchers worldwide. It is managed for its historical and cultural significance.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued preservation and conservation efforts as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, ongoing archaeological research to uncover more historical details, and sustainable development of tourism infrastructure to manage visitor flow and enhance the visitor experience while protecting the site.
